summary: A series of internal Bureau of Prisons emails from the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York concerning inmate Jeffrey Epstein's psychological state, suicide risk assessments, and conditions of confinement in July 2019, shortly before his death. The emails show staff were proactively monitoring him due to risk factors and his apparent distress.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The incarcerated individual who is the subject of all email communications, being monitored for psychological distress and suicide risk following a court appearance.

persons.name: Dr. Central Office
persons.context: A psychologist from the BOP Central Office consulted regarding inmate Epstein's suicide risk factors and recommended a suicide risk assessment.

connections.description: Dr. Central Office was consulted to assess Epstein's suicide risk and recommended specific monitoring protocols for him.

events.title: Court Proceeding and Suicide Risk Alert
events.description: Epstein was in court and was expected to receive bad news regarding his legal situation. The BOP Central Office recommended a suicide risk assessment upon his return due to his high-profile case, sex offense charges, and pre-trial status.

events.title: Epstein Observed Distraught
events.description: A correctional officer observed inmate Epstein as distraught, sad, confused, dazed, and withdrawn during the 10:00 PM count, prompting a request for a psychology consultation.

events.title: Medication Adjustment
events.description: Epstein's medication (Colace and milk of magnesia) was adjusted from a 30-day supply to a 15-day self-carry supply.

events.title: SHU Transition and Health Complaints
events.description: Epstein reported numbness in his arm and neck, sleep issues due to a lack of his CPAP machine, and complained about noise in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). He was transitioned from psychological observation back to the SHU.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: BOP staff identified Jeffrey Epstein as having multiple risk factors for suicidality on July 8, 2019, including a high-profile case, sex offense charges, pre-trial status, and an impending court proceeding where he was likely to receive bad news.
A suicide risk assessment was ordered for Epstein upon his return from court on July 8, with instructions to place him on psychological observation or suicide watch if necessary.
On July 6, 2019, a correctional officer found Epstein to be 'distraught sad and a little confused' and 'dazed and withdrawn,' prompting an alert to psychology staff.

In late July, Epstein complained of physical symptoms (numbness in arm/neck), an inability to sleep without his CPAP machine, and psychological distress from the noise and conditions in the Special Housing Unit (SHU).
The emails document a series of internal communications showing proactive but routine monitoring of Epstein's psychological state in the weeks leading up to his death.
